stem: A 21-year-old client with bulimia nervosa presents with sudden, sharp chest pain after an episode of self-induced vomiting. Based on the documentation in the Serial GI & Metabolic Surveillance Log, which condition is the most likely cause of the client's current status?

rationale.correct: The client is experiencing Boerhaave Syndrome (a1), a full-thickness rupture of the esophagus due to the pressure of forceful vomiting. Key findings include pneumomediastinum (air escaping into the chest), subcutaneous emphysema (crepitus in the neck), and pleural fluid positive for salivary amylase (spit leaking into the chest). The client's shock (BP 82/48) and fever (102.4°F) indicate mediastinitis. This condition is a surgical emergency with high mortality if untreated, unlike a Mallory-Weiss tear (a2), which is a mucosal laceration causing bleeding. Mallory-Weiss tears are typically self-limiting and heal without surgical intervention.
clinicalPearls: Macler's Triad for Boerhaave Syndrome: Vomiting, Chest Pain, Subcutaneous Emphysema.
A crunching sound heard with the heartbeat (Hamman's Crunch) indicates pneumomediastinum.
Management of Boerhaave Syndrome is similar to major trauma: NPO, IV antibiotics, and emergent surgical intervention.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting Mallory-Weiss tear (a2) because it is a more commonly recognized complication of eating disorders.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the presence of air. If air is detected in the neck (crepitus) or chest (pneumomediastinum), suspect a full-thickness esophageal rupture (Boerhaave Syndrome). Mallory-Weiss tear involves only a superficial mucosal laceration and bleeding. Boerhaave's syndrome is a surgical emergency.

exhibits.title: SBAR
exhibits.content:
S: 21-year-old female reports sudden onset of severe, sharp chest pain after an episode of self-induced vomiting. Pain is rated 9/10.
B: History of bulimia nervosa for 8 years, with frequent purging episodes (4-6 times daily). No known allergies. Last oral intake was 08:00.
A: Client is in acute distress, pale, and diaphoretic. Vital signs: BP 82/48 mmHg, HR 142 bpm, RR 32, SpO2 92% on room air, Temp 102.4°F (39.1°C). Auscultation reveals diminished breath sounds on the left. Palpation reveals crepitus in the neck and chest wall.
R: STAT chest X-ray and CT scan with contrast to rule out esophageal rupture. NPO status. Administer IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Prepare for possible surgical intervention. Notify the attending physician immediately.

exhibits.title: Labs
exhibits.content:
WBC: 22,000/mm3
Pleural Fluid Analysis: Positive for salivary amylase

exhibits.title: Radiology
exhibits.content:
Chest X-ray: Pneumomediastinum (air in the mediastinum). Left-sided pleural effusion. No pulmonary nodules.
CT Chest with Contrast: Extravasation of oral contrast into the pleural space.
